Award.AwardTitle: Ferromagnetic Resonance of Interacting Particles: A Theoretical Study (Renewal)
Award.AbstractNarration:
In nearly any body of fresh or salt water, there is a depth at which bacteria can be found that manufacture chains of magnets. Called magnetotactic bacteria, they use the chains of magnets to orient themselves in the Earth's field, and this helps them find the depth at which they can thrive. When they die, the magnets remain as "magnetofossils"; they are one of the few groups of microorganism to leave a permanent record. This record provides not only information on the bacteria, but also the environmental conditions they experienced; and in layers where the magnets are found, they provide a record of the Earth's magnetic field around the time the bacteria died. Paleomagnetists have attempted to develop magnetic methods that reliably identify magnetofossils in sediments; but these methods cannot always discriminate between magnetic minerals produced by bacteria and inorganic magnetic minerals.

A test developed by a group at Caltech shows promise. They use ferromagnetic resonance (FMR), which involves exposing a sample to microwave-frequency electromagnetic fields and measuring the magnetic response. This may be the only test that can distinguish a chain of magnets from a single elongated magnet. However, the existing theory for FMR cannot model more than one magnet if they interact with each other through their magnetic fields. In this project, the PI will develop software that implements a general theory of FMR for interacting single-domain magnets (ones that act like dipoles). It will be general enough to allow the sizes, shapes and orientations to vary. The software will be capable not just of modeling the output of commercial electron spin resonance spectrometers, which only measure power absorption in a single sample orientation, but also instruments that can rotate the sample and obtain phase information. The software will be used to calculate FMR spectra for chains of magnets, as they are in live bacteria, and changes in the spectra as the chains become disrupted and the magnets oxidized after the bacteria die. It will be used to determine when FMR can be used to reliably identify magnetofossils.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Very small ferromagnetic minerals, tens of microns in size, have an important role in environmental processes such as the iron cycle, soil formation and magnetic navigation in bacteria. They are also the only minerals that reliably record the intensity of the Earth’s magnetic field in the past. This is due to their distinctive magnetic properties that are due to a combination of rotation of the magnetic moment and hopping over energy barriers because of thermal fluctuations. Where thermal fluctuations dominate, the minerals are superparamagnetic; where rotation dominates, they are single-domain.

 

Paleomagnetists and environmental magnetists hope to use the distinctive magnetic properties to detect and characterize these minerals. However, to date these efforts have not been wholly successful because of the multiple factors that affect the magnetism. These include volume, shape and magnetostatic interactions between minerals.

 

The focus of this project was on developing the theory for two methods that may be effective in characterizing small magnetic minerals. The first is ferromagnetic resonance (FMR), which involves subjecting a sample to a microwave-frequency field and measuring the response. The theory for this has previously been worked out for isolated magnets, but here I tackle the much harder problem of interacting magnets. Most of the work involved creating code to find the starting states for FMR and then using a linearized theory to determine the response.

 

The first part, finding the starting states, involved code based on numerical algebraic geometry. It finds not just the stable states but also the states that determine the heights of energy barriers over which barrier hopping occurs. The latter part has always been a major challenge. I developed and published a package called BertiniLab, which runs on the mathematical software system Matlab and forms an interface to Bertini, the main engine for solving such problems. On top of this is the software that formulates the  magnetic problem for Bertini. Applications to small systems shows a rich structure that cannot be predicted by standard phenomenological models. Attached to this software is another module that uses information on the stable states to calculate the FMR response.

 

The other type of measurement, frequency dependence of susceptibility, involves small magnetic fields oscillating at tens to thousands of hertz. A particularly useful feature of these measurements is that the output has an in-phase and and out-of-phase component, and the latter only responds to nanometer-scale magnets. The theory has previously been done only for magnets whose symmetry axes are aligned with the field. This was generalized to arbitrary orientations. It was shown how the frequency dependence could be represented by a parameter that can place tight constraints on the volume distribution, and there is potential for also finding the shape distribution. In addition, the first detailed study of the directional dependence of susceptibility was done using an angular probability distribution derived from a widely used model of rock deformation. For large deformations, this proved to be quite different from the directional dependence that is usually assumed.

 

Together, these measurements involving magnetic fields oscillating over a wide range of frequencies have great potential for characterizing the volumes, shapes and magnetostatic interactions of this important class of magnetic minerals. Nanoscale magnets are also widely used in physics and chemistry, and this work provides better tools to model them and characterized them. These are the main intellectual merits of this work.

 

The work has broader impacts in that the characterization of these minerals can be used to provide information on past environmental processes, particularly climate change and pollution.
